Table Formats : Delta Lake & Apache Iceberg

Du Data Lake au Data Lakehouse

Bienvenue dans ce module oÃ¹ tu vas transformer un Data Lake en Data Lakehouse â€” combinant flexibilitÃ© et ACID.

PrÃ©requis

Module CompÃ©tence Pourquoi ?
âœ… 19 PySpark Advanced DataFrame API
âœ… 20 Spark SQL SQL, Catalyst
âœ… 22 Cloud Storage MinIO, s3a://

Objectifs

  • Comprendre pourquoi Parquet seul ne suffit pas
  • MaÃ®triser ACID pour les Data Lakes
  • Utiliser Delta Lake : MERGE, Time Travel, Schema Evolution
  • Comprendre Iceberg : Hidden Partitioning
  • Optimiser avec OPTIMIZE, Z-ORDER, VACUUM

1. Introduction â€” Pourquoi les Table Formats ?

1.1 Lâ€™Ã©volution du stockage

2000s: DATA WAREHOUSE     2010s: DATA LAKE        2020s: LAKEHOUSE
â€¢ Oracle, Teradata        â€¢ Hadoop, S3+Parquet    â€¢ Delta, Iceberg
â€¢ ACID âœ…                 â€¢ Flexible              â€¢ ACID âœ…
â€¢ CoÃ»teux ğŸ’°              â€¢ Pas ACID âŒ           â€¢ Flexible
â€¢ Rigide                  â€¢ Cheap ğŸ’µ              â€¢ Cheap ğŸ’µ

1.2 Le problÃ¨me avec Parquet seul

ScÃ©nario ProblÃ¨me
Deux jobs Ã©crivent en mÃªme temps ğŸ’¥ DonnÃ©es corrompues
UPDATE 100 lignes sur 10M ğŸ˜° RÃ©Ã©crire toute la partition
Job Ã©choue Ã  mi-chemin ğŸ—‘ï¸ Fichiers partiels
Voir donnÃ©es dâ€™il y a 3 jours âŒ Impossible
SchÃ©ma source change ğŸ’” Erreurs de lecture

Les Table Formats rÃ©solvent TOUS ces problÃ¨mes.

1.3 Câ€™est quoi un Data Lakehouse ?

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                  DATA LAKEHOUSE                     â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚   DATA LAKE          +       DATA WAREHOUSE         â”‚
â”‚   â€¢ Stockage cheap           â€¢ ACID                 â”‚
â”‚   â€¢ Formats ouverts          â€¢ Schema enforce       â”‚
â”‚   â€¢ FlexibilitÃ©              â€¢ SQL performant       â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚   = Le meilleur des deux mondes !                   â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Les Table Formats ajoutent une couche de mÃ©tadonnÃ©es (Transaction Log) au-dessus des fichiers Parquet.

Exercice 1 : Identifier les limites de Parquet

ScÃ©nario ProblÃ¨me ?
Job A lit pendant que Job B Ã©crit ?
UPDATE 100 lignes sur 10M ?
Suppression accidentelle dâ€™une partition ?
ğŸ’¡ RÃ©ponses
  • Dirty Read : donnÃ©es partielles/incohÃ©rentes
  • RÃ©Ã©criture totale : toute la partition
  • Pas de rollback : donnÃ©es perdues

2. Les Limites du Data Lake Classique

2.1 Pas de transactions ACID

PropriÃ©tÃ© Signification Parquet seul ?
Atomicity Tout-ou-rien âŒ Fichiers partiels
Consistency Contraintes respectÃ©es âŒ Pas de validation
Isolation OpÃ©rations isolÃ©es âŒ Dirty reads
Durability DonnÃ©es persistantes âœ… Sur S3

2.2 Mutations coÃ»teuses

UPDATE 1 ligne = lire 10M lignes â†’ modifier â†’ rÃ©Ã©crire 10M lignes = minutes

2.3 Small Files Problem

Streaming 5min/jour = 288 fichiers/jour Ã— 365 = 100K+ fichiers/an

2.4 SchÃ©ma rigide

Pas de schema enforcement natif. Changer partitionnement = rÃ©Ã©criture totale.

3. Introduction aux Table Formats

3.1 Architecture

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚           QUERY ENGINE (Spark, Trino)       â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                      â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚         TABLE FORMAT LAYER                  â”‚
â”‚      (Delta Lake / Iceberg / Hudi)          â”‚
â”‚  â€¢ Transaction Log                          â”‚
â”‚  â€¢ ACID, Time Travel, Schema Evolution      â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                      â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚     FILE FORMAT (Parquet) sur STORAGE (S3)  â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

3.2 Le Transaction Log

Version 0 : ADD file_001.parquet
Version 1 : ADD file_002.parquet
Version 2 : ADD file_003.parquet, REMOVE file_001.parquet

Ã‰tat actuel = { file_002, file_003 }
Ã‰tat v1     = { file_001, file_002 }  â† Time Travel !

3.3 Comparaison Delta vs Iceberg vs Hudi

CritÃ¨re Delta Lake Iceberg Hudi
CrÃ©ateur Databricks Netflix Uber
Moteurs Spark +++ Multi-engine Spark, Flink
ACID âœ… âœ… âœ…
Time Travel âœ…âœ… âœ…âœ… âœ…
Schema Evolution âœ… âœ…âœ… (best) âœ…
Hidden Partitioning âŒ âœ… (unique!) âŒ
Z-Ordering âœ… âœ… âŒ
Catalog requis Optionnel Obligatoire Obligatoire
CDC natif Change Data Feed âŒ âœ…âœ… (best)

3.4 Lequel choisir ?

  • ğŸ¯ Delta Lake : Spark, Databricks, simplicitÃ©, dÃ©butants
  • ğŸ¯ Iceberg : Multi-engine, Hidden Partitioning, AWS Athena
  • ğŸ¯ Hudi : CDC massif, near-real-time, AWS EMR

4. Delta Lake â€” Deep Dive

4.1 Architecture : _delta_log/

s3://bucket/sales/
â”œâ”€â”€ _delta_log/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00000000000000000000.json  â† Version 0
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00000000000000000001.json  â† Version 1
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00000000000000000010.checkpoint.parquet
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ _last_checkpoint
â”œâ”€â”€ part-00000-abc.parquet
â””â”€â”€ part-00001-def.parquet

Chaque JSON contient :

  • add : nouveau fichier ajoutÃ©
  • remove : fichier retirÃ©
  • commitInfo : mÃ©tadonnÃ©es de lâ€™opÃ©ration
  • stats : min/max pour Data Skipping
Voir le code 
# Configuration Spark avec Delta Lake

config = '''
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

spark = SparkSession.builder \
    .appName("Delta Lake Demo") \
    .config("spark.jars.packages", "io.delta:delta-spark_2.12:3.1.0") \
    .config("spark.sql.extensions", "io.delta.sql.DeltaSparkSessionExtension") \
    .config("spark.sql.catalog.spark_catalog", "org.apache.spark.sql.delta.catalog.DeltaCatalog") \
    .getOrCreate()

# Pour MinIO
spark.conf.set("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.endpoint", "http://localhost:9000")
spark.conf.set("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.access.key", "minioadmin")
spark.conf.set("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.secret.key", "minioadmin")
spark.conf.set("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.path.style.access", "true")
'''
print(config)
Voir le code 
# CrÃ©er une table Delta

create_examples = '''
# MÃ‰THODE 1 : Depuis DataFrame
df = spark.createDataFrame([
    (1, "Alice", 1200.0, "2024-01-15"),
    (2, "Bob", 350.0, "2024-01-15"),
], ["id", "customer", "amount", "date"])

df.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").save("s3a://silver/sales/")

# MÃ‰THODE 2 : SQL
spark.sql("""
    CREATE TABLE sales (id INT, customer STRING, amount DOUBLE, date DATE)
    USING DELTA
    LOCATION 's3a://silver/sales/'
""")

# MÃ‰THODE 3 : Convertir Parquet existant (SANS copie !)
spark.sql("CONVERT TO DELTA parquet.`s3a://bronze/old_table/`")
'''
print(create_examples)

4.4 MERGE INTO : CDC et Upsert

TARGET               SOURCE CDC             APRÃˆS MERGE
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”      â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ id â”‚ name  â”‚      â”‚ id â”‚ name  â”‚ op â”‚    â”‚ id â”‚ name  â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤      â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤    â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ 1  â”‚ Alice â”‚      â”‚ 1  â”‚ Alice â”‚ U  â”‚ â†’  â”‚ 1  â”‚ ALICE â”‚ Updated
â”‚ 2  â”‚ Bob   â”‚      â”‚ 3  â”‚ New   â”‚ I  â”‚ â†’  â”‚ 3  â”‚ New   â”‚ Inserted
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜      â”‚ 2  â”‚ Bob   â”‚ D  â”‚    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜ (Bob deleted)
                    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
Voir le code 
# MERGE INTO - Exemple complet

merge_sql = '''
MERGE INTO target_table AS target
USING source_cdc AS source
ON target.id = source.id

WHEN MATCHED AND source.op = 'D' THEN DELETE

WHEN MATCHED AND source.op = 'U' THEN
    UPDATE SET target.name = source.name, target.amount = source.amount

WHEN NOT MATCHED THEN
    INSERT (id, name, amount) VALUES (source.id, source.name, source.amount)
'''

merge_python = '''
from delta.tables import DeltaTable

target = DeltaTable.forPath(spark, "s3a://silver/customers/")
source = spark.read.parquet("s3a://bronze/cdc/")

target.alias("t").merge(source.alias("s"), "t.id = s.id") \
    .whenMatchedDelete(condition="s.op = 'D'") \
    .whenMatchedUpdate(condition="s.op = 'U'", set={"name": "s.name"}) \
    .whenNotMatchedInsert(values={"id": "s.id", "name": "s.name"}) \
    .execute()
'''

print("SQL:", merge_sql)
print("\nPython:", merge_python)

Exercice 3 : CDC avec MERGE INTO

# Initial
initial = [(1, "Alice"), (2, "Bob")]

# CDC
cdc = [(1, "ALICE", "U"), (3, "New", "I"), (2, None, "D")]

# TODO: CrÃ©er table, appliquer MERGE
ğŸ’¡ Solution 
target = DeltaTable.forPath(spark, "/tmp/customers")
target.alias("t").merge(df_cdc.alias("s"), "t.id = s.id") \
    .whenMatchedDelete(condition="s.op = 'D'") \
    .whenMatchedUpdate(condition="s.op = 'U'", set={"name": "s.name"}) \
    .whenNotMatchedInsert(values={"id": "s.id", "name": "s.name"}) \
    .execute()

4.5 Time Travel

Version 0     Version 1     Version 2     Version 3
(Create)      (INSERT)      (UPDATE)      (DELETE)
   â”‚              â”‚              â”‚              â”‚
   â–¼              â–¼              â–¼              â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”   â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”   â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”   â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ 1 row  â”‚ â†’ â”‚ 3 rows â”‚ â†’ â”‚ 3 rows â”‚ â†’ â”‚ 2 rows â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜   â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜   â”‚modifiedâ”‚   â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Tu peux lire N'IMPORTE quelle version !
Voir le code 
# Time Travel

time_travel = '''
# Voir l'historique
spark.sql("DESCRIBE HISTORY sales").show()

# Lire par version
df_v1 = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM sales VERSION AS OF 1")
df_v1 = spark.read.format("delta").option("versionAsOf", 1).load("path/")

# Lire par timestamp
df = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM sales TIMESTAMP AS OF '2024-01-03 12:00:00'")

# RESTORE : Revenir Ã  une version
spark.sql("RESTORE TABLE sales TO VERSION AS OF 5")
'''

print(time_travel)
print("\nğŸ’¡ Use cases: Audit, rollback, debug, ML reproductibility")

Exercice 4 : Restaurer aprÃ¨s erreur

# OUPS ! DELETE sans WHERE
spark.sql("DELETE FROM sales")

# TODO: Utiliser Time Travel pour restaurer
ğŸ’¡ Solution 
spark.sql("DESCRIBE HISTORY sales").show()  # Trouver version avant DELETE
spark.sql("RESTORE TABLE sales TO VERSION AS OF 1")

4.6 Schema Management

Mode Comportement Option
Enforcement Rejette schÃ©mas diffÃ©rents (dÃ©faut)
Evolution Ajoute nouvelles colonnes mergeSchema=true
Overwrite Remplace schÃ©ma entier overwriteSchema=true 
# Schema Evolution
df_new.write.format("delta") \
    .mode("append") \
    .option("mergeSchema", "true") \
    .save("path/")

5. Apache Iceberg â€” Deep Dive

5.1 Architecture

s3://bucket/sales/
â”œâ”€â”€ metadata/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ v1.metadata.json     â† Metadata File
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ snap-xxx.avro        â† Manifest List
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ xxx-m0.avro          â† Manifest File
â””â”€â”€ data/
    â””â”€â”€ part-00000.parquet

Structure arborescente vs log sÃ©quentiel = plus rapide pour grandes tables.

5.2 Hidden Partitioning (Killer Feature)

CREATE TABLE events (
    event_id LONG,
    event_ts TIMESTAMP,
    user_id LONG
)
USING iceberg
PARTITIONED BY (
    days(event_ts),      -- Partition par jour (cachÃ© !)
    bucket(16, user_id)  -- Bucket hash
)

-- L'utilisateur n'a PAS besoin de connaÃ®tre le partitionnement !
SELECT * FROM events WHERE event_ts = '2024-01-15 10:00:00'
-- Partition pruning automatique !

Transforms : years(), months(), days(), hours(), bucket(N, col), truncate(L, col)

Exercice 5 : Table Iceberg avec Hidden Partitioning

ğŸ’¡ Solution 
CREATE TABLE my_catalog.db.page_views (
    view_id LONG, view_timestamp TIMESTAMP, user_id LONG
)
USING iceberg
PARTITIONED BY (days(view_timestamp), bucket(8, user_id))

5.3 Schema Evolution avancÃ©e

ALTER TABLE events ADD COLUMN source STRING
ALTER TABLE events RENAME COLUMN payload TO event_data  -- Sans rÃ©Ã©criture !
ALTER TABLE events DROP COLUMN deprecated              -- Sans rÃ©Ã©criture !

5.4 Catalog (obligatoire)

Iceberg nÃ©cessite un catalog : Hive Metastore, AWS Glue, Nessie, Unity Catalog.

7. Maintenance & Optimisation

7.1 Compaction (OPTIMIZE)

-- Delta
OPTIMIZE sales
OPTIMIZE sales WHERE date >= '2024-01-01'

-- Iceberg
CALL catalog.system.rewrite_data_files(table => 'db.sales')

7.2 Z-Ordering

Organise donnÃ©es par colonnes filtrÃ©es â†’ meilleur Data Skipping.

OPTIMIZE sales ZORDER BY (customer_id, product_id)

RÃ¨gle : Partition par faible cardinalitÃ©, Z-ORDER par haute cardinalitÃ©.

7.3 VACUUM

-- Supprimer fichiers > 7 jours
VACUUM sales
VACUUM sales RETAIN 168 HOURS

-- Iceberg
CALL catalog.system.expire_snapshots(table => 'db.sales', retain_last => 5)

âš ï¸ AprÃ¨s VACUUM, Time Travel sur versions supprimÃ©es impossible !

Exercice 7 : Compacter une table

# VÃ©rifier fichiers avant
spark.sql("DESCRIBE DETAIL delta.`path`").select("numFiles").show()

# TODO: OPTIMIZE + ZORDER

# VÃ©rifier aprÃ¨s

8. Migration Parquet â†’ Delta

8.1 Conversion in-place (SANS copie !)

CONVERT TO DELTA parquet.`s3a://bronze/old_table/`
CONVERT TO DELTA parquet.`s3a://bronze/partitioned/`
    PARTITIONED BY (date STRING)

CrÃ©e _delta_log/ sans dÃ©placer les donnÃ©es. Temps : secondes.

8.2 Migration avec CTAS

CREATE TABLE new_delta USING DELTA AS
SELECT * FROM parquet.`s3a://bronze/old/`

9. Apache Hudi â€” AperÃ§u

Copy-on-Write vs Merge-on-Read

CoW MoR
Ã‰criture RÃ©Ã©crit fichier entier (ğŸ¢) Ã‰crit delta log (ğŸš€)

Use case Lectures frÃ©quentes CDC intensif

Quand utiliser Hudi : CDC massif, near-real-time, AWS EMR.

Quiz

Q1. Pourquoi Parquet seul ne garantit pas ACID ?
R Pas de Transaction Log pour atomicitÃ©/isolation.
Q2. DiffÃ©rence Schema Enforcement vs Evolution ?
R Enforcement rejette, Evolution adapte.
Q3. Quel format supporte Hidden Partitioning ?
R Apache Iceberg uniquement.
Q4. RÃ´le du Transaction Log Delta ?
R Enregistre add/remove pour ACID et Time Travel.
Q5. Objectif de ZORDER BY ?
R Organiser donnÃ©es pour meilleur Data Skipping.
Q6. Quelle opÃ©ration supprime les vieux fichiers ?
R VACUUM (Delta) ou expire_snapshots (Iceberg).
